On 1 April 2020, an Ethiopian national was severely assaulted and another fatally assaulted by police in Isipingo (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal) during the national coronavirus lockdown enforcement.
On 1 April 2020, a man was fatally assaulted while in police custody in Lenasia (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng), within the context of coronavirus-related policing.
On 1 April 2020, a man was fatally assaulted while being in police custody in Lenasia (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng).

On 1 April 2020, a scuffle broke out between community members and police in Isipingo (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal) during the enforcement of the national coronavirus lockdown. An Ethiopian national was killed and a local injured. [size=no report]

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: On 1 April 2020, ANCYL members demonstrated at a supermarket in Waterkloof in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), demanding the closure of the store due to a lack of protective gear against coronavirus for workers. [size=no report]

On 2 April 2020, defence force soldiers allegedly raided a house and assaulted a man and his daughter in Eerste River in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape), during enforcement operations for the national coronavirus lockdown.

On 4 April 2020, police officers allegedly assaulted a man and his wife at Komani police station in Queenstown (Chris Hani, Eastern Cape), after they were arrested for allegedly breaking the national coronavirus lockdown laws.

On 9 April 2020, a man was beaten with a firearm by police and shot seven times with rubber bullets at Mayfield in Daveyton (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng) during the national coronavirus lockdown.

On 10 April 2020, a man was fatally assaulted by soldiers in Alexandra (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) when he and a friend were allegedly caught drinking inside their front yard, against coronavirus regulations.

On 12 April 2020, about 60 residents demonstrated in Khayelitsha (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) after their shacks were demolished. Police used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. [size=about 60]

At some shops, hundreds of community members stopped the mob by gathering outside the shops. Police fired tear gas, stun grenades and rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. One officer was injured when a rioter threw her with a stone. [size=no report]

On 15 April 2020, three people were arrested in Vlakfontein (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) in connection with a suspected mob attack that left a man dead. According to reports, about 13 people went to the deceased's house, demanding property that was stolen and tied the man up. The body of the man was later discovered in an open field. [size=at least 13]

On 16 April 2020, about 40 people demonstrated in Rosedale near Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape), demanding food parcels to mitigate the effects of the coronavirus lockdown. [size=about 40]

On 16 April 2020, a man was fatally shot by police in Groblershoop (Siyanda, Northern Cape).

column17: On 22 April 2020, the Land Invasion Unit used by the municipality used live ammunition to evict people from a piece of land they used for housing in Cato Crest, Durban (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal).

The group called for the end of racism and for the naming of the person who approved the advertisement and for all TRESemme products to be recalled for 10 days. [size=no report]

Around 9 September 2020 (week of), about 73 Hanes, formerly known as Playtex, workers who were dismissed for demonstrating outside the factory in Durban (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal) over unpaid Unemployment Insurance Fund (UIF) payments during the national coronavirus lockdown in June (coded separately), demonstrated outside the factory again. [size=about 73]

On 9 September 2020, residents marched to the municipal offices in Denneboom near Mamelodi (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), demonstrating against the unlawful relocation of residents who were victims of a flood. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, taxi drivers barricaded roads in Parkdene in George (Eden, Western Cape) with rocks and litter. The demonstration is suspected to be over the rollout of a new bus route. Police used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, three men, accused of murder, were fatally attacked by community members in Rhwantsana near Cacadu (Cacadu, Eastern Cape). Earlier, community members had a meeting with police over the crime in the area. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, community members barricaded Watt and Commercial Roads with burning tires and other obstacles in Dundee (uMzinyathi, KwaZulu-Natal). The demonstration was reportedly housing related. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, residents damaged two City Power vehicles and a police car in Alexandra (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) when City Power attempted to remove illegal electricity connections. Police used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, EFF members demonstrated in front of the Clicks store at the Mall of Africa in Midrand (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) for the third day against an advertisement posted by the store and TRESemme depicting black women's hair as frizzy, dull and damaged, comparing it with images of white women's hair which was described as was fine, flat and normal. The group called for the end of racism and for the naming of the person who approved the advertisement and for all TRESemme products to be recalled for 10 days. The demonstration reportedly turned violent. [size=no report]

column16: Daily Sun (South Africa); Daily Dispatch; Daily News (South Africa)
column17: On 9 September 2020, scores of artists gathered outside the court in Pinetown (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) during the bail hearing of artists who were arrested during a demonstration a week earlier (coded separately) on the N3 in Durban. [size=scores]

Around 9 September 2020 (week of), community members from 90 villages and 31 municipal wards marched to the municipal buildings in Giyani (Mopani, Limpopo) to demonstrate against the alleged nepotism within the municipality. The demonstrators demanded the reversal of the appointment of family members in critical and junior positions by the municipal manager and corporate service director. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, students, mostly girls, demonstrated at the Bracken High School in Alberton (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng) accusing teachers of emotionally and physically abusing them. The demonstration was sparked by a teacher telling a schoolgirl that her short skirt would be the reason that she would get raped. [size=no report]

On 9 September 2020, community members demonstrated outside the court in Parkwood (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) during the court hearing of a man accused of killing a young boy during a shootout between gang members, demanding justice. [size=no report]

On 10 September 2020, community members demonstrated outside the court in Soweto (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) during the hearing of two police officers accused of fatally shooting a teenager living with Down syndrome, calling for justice. [size=no report]

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: Around 10 September 2020 (as reported), ANCYL marched to the Walter Sisulu House in East London (Buffalo City, Eastern Cape) calling for the dissolving of structures where older generations are in positions of power to look after South Africa's youth. [size=no report]
On 10 September 2020, a man who attempted to kidnap a child at a restaurant in Florida (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) was attacked by a mob who attempted to apprehend him. [size=no report]

On 10 September 2020, EFF members demonstrated in front of the Clicks store at the Mall of Africa in Midrand (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) for the fourth day against an advertisement posted by the store and TRESemme depicting black women's hair as frizzy, dull and damaged, comparing it with images of white women's hair which was described as was fine, flat and normal. The group called for the end of racism and for the naming of the person who approved the advertisement and for all TRESemme products to be recalled for 10 days. [size=no report]

column7: ANCWL: African National Congress Womens League; Women (South Africa)
column17: On 10 September 2020, women, led by the ANCWL, demonstrated outside the court in Colenso (uThukela, KwaZulu-Natal) during the hearing of a man and women accused of killing a teacher. [size=no report]

On 10 September 2020, ten municipal workers barricaded the entrance of the Nelspruit Licensing Department in Mbombela (Ehlanzeni, Mpumalanga) with rubble. The demonstration was over unpaid coronavirus benefits payments. [size=10]

On 10 September 2020, three Lesotho nationals were killed with knobkieries (a fighting stick, usually with a knob on the end). Their bodies were found on a farm in Fouriesburg (Lejweleputswa, Free State). According to some eye witnesses, the victims had earlier that morning been seen with three police officers, allegedly from Lesotho who were following information about stock theft that occurred in Lesotho.

column16: Times (South Africa); Citizen (South Africa); News24 (South Africa)
column17: On 10 September 2020, a scuffle broke out between EFF members and security guards in Norkem Mall in Kempton Park (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng). EFF members demonstrated in front of the Clicks store against an advertisement posted by the store and TRESemme depicting black women's hair as frizzy, dull and damaged, comparing it with images of white women's hair which was described as was fine, flat and normal. The group called for the end of racism and for the naming of the person who approved the advertisement and for all TRESemme products to be recalled for 10 days. One of the EFF members was allegedly assaulted by security guards. [size=no report]

column16: Daily Sun (South Africa); News24 (South Africa); Cape Argus
column17: On 10 September 2020, EFF members demonstrated in front of the Clicks store in Stellenbosch (Cape Winelands, Western Cape) against an advertisement posted by the store and TRESemme depicting black women's hair as frizzy, dull and damaged, comparing it with images of white women's hair which was described as was fine, flat and normal. The group called for the end of racism and for the naming of the person who approved the advertisement and for all TRESemme products to be recalled for 10 days. Police arrested 16 people. [size=at least 16]

On 10 September 2020, a taxi driver was shot by unknown assailant(s) in Bellville (City of Cape Town, Western Cape). He later died of his injuries. The taxi hub has recently seen a spike in shooting activities. A taxi dispute over a route has been reported in the area.
Around 11 September 2020 (as reported), residents from Malabar (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) demonstrated over the closure of the local clinic due to gang related incidents. [size=no report]

On 11 September 2020, EFF members demonstrated outside the BMW dealership in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) after an advertisement was posted for a vacancy for a white man or woman. [size=no report]

On 11 September 2020, taxi association demonstrations were reported in Polokwane (Capricorn, Limpopo). Taxis blocked Grobler Street for hours. A group pelted stones at a taxi in Buite street. A taxi driver (assumed from an opposed taxi association) fires shots at the group, injuring one. [size=no report]

column16: GroundUp; Pretoria News; News24 (South Africa); Daily Sun (South Africa)
column17: On 11 September 2020, about 40 Mpumalanga residents demonstrated at the Union Buildings in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), demanding progress on the proposed Moloto Road and rail corridor. [size=about 40]

On 11 September 2020, 15 artists marched to the Union Buildings in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) to hand over a memorandum. The memorandum related to coronavirus relief funds not received and the closure of all entertainment facilities during the lockdown. [size=15]

On 11 September 2020, about 40 people from Thembisile Hani, Dr JS Moroka, and Elias Motsoaledi municipalities demonstrated at the Union Building in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), demanding a rail corridor to be built. [size=about 40]
On 11 September 2020, a church group and the Salvation Army marched to the Vryheid police station (Zululand, KwaZulu-Natal) to deliver a memorandum on gender-based violence. [size=no report]

On 11 September 2020, about 70 EFF members demonstrated outside J.A Floral in Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) after four female staff were allegedly made to reveal if they were menstruating after some blood was left in a staff toilet. Police used stun grenades to disperse the crowd. Four demonstrators were arrested. [size=about 70]

On 11 September 2020, hundreds of community members demonstrated at the Ocean Basket (restaurant) in Mall of the North in Polokwane (Capricorn, Limpopo) after a restaurant owner and her mother was murdered the day before. [size=hundreds]
On 11 September 2020, Move One Million members demonstrated in Hillcrest in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) against corruption. [size=no report]
On 13 September 2020, about 25 zama-zamas (unlawful miners) shot at a security guard in Carletonville (West Rand, Gauteng). The security guard survived the attack.

On 14 September 2020, EFF members demonstrated outside the court in Randburg (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) during the case hearing of the EFF leader and a MP accused of assaulting a police officer in 2018 (coded separately) in Soweto during the state funeral of a political activist. [size=no report]

On 14 September 2020, about 30 farmers demonstrated at the court in Ventersdorp (Dr Kenneth Kaunda, North-West) during the bail hearing of six men accused of shooting and injuring a farmer during a farm attack in Klerkskraal, demanding bail to be denied. [size=about 30]

Around 14 September 2020 (as reported), residents demonstrated at the Thornton Road Primary School in Crawford (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) against the planned building of a cell tower on the school grounds. The demonstrators said they have not been consulted about the cell tower. [size=no report]

On 14 September 2020, about 50 undertakers demonstrated in Durban (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal), demanding that the industry be regulated and that by-laws be amended by municipalities to enable cluster storage. [size=about 50]

This followed a series of stories that were published by Sedibeng Ster about a group of patrollers that has apparently become a law unto themselves in Boipatong. [size=about 5]

column16: Daily Dispatch; Times (South Africa); North Coast Courier
column17: On 15 September 2020, about 200 community members barricaded road in Pomeroy (uMzinyathi, KwaZulu-Natal) with burning tires and stones and damaged some infrastructure in a demonstration over a lack of water in the area. Police were on the scene (no mention of intervention). [size=about 200]

On 15 September 2020, parents of pupils in Inkqubela Primary School demonstrated outside the school in Kwazakhele (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape), demanding fencing around the school that had been vandalized. [size=no report]
On 15 September 2020, church leaders held a silent demonstration at the St George's Cathedral in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) against corruption. [size=no report]

On 15 September 2020, about 100 students from TVET colleges and Nelson Mandela University marched to the Port Elizabeth City Hall (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) to hand over a memorandum, The students are demanding that the municipality fulfil a previous commitment to convert derelict buildings in the metro into student accommodation at low rentals. [size=about 100]

On 15 September 2020, masses demonstrated outside the court in Polokwane (Capricorn, Limpopo) during the case hearing of two men accused of killing a restaurant owner and her mother, calling for justice to take its course. [size=masses]

On 15 September 2020, about 50 residents demonstrated at Parliament in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape), claiming the city failed to respond to their calls for assistance with an overflowing sewage canal. [size=about 50]
On 15 September 2020, church leaders held a silent demonstration at the Union Buildings in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) against corruption. [size=no report]

On 15 September 2020, hundreds of taxi drivers barricaded the Mew Way bridge in Khayelitsha (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) during a taxi route dispute between Congress for Democratic Taxi Association and the Cape Amalgamated Taxi Association. [size=hundreds]

On 15 September 2020, two men, in Nanduwa patrol cars (Taxi association patrol vehicles), were fatally shot by three armed men near Nancefield Hostel in Soweto (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng). The incident is suspected to be related to taxi violence.

On 15 September 2020, Tokyo informal settlement residents barricaded roads with burning tires and three vehicles were set alight in Germiston (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng) over service delivery issues in the area. Police used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. [size=no report]

column7: TUMSA: Trade Union of Musicians of South Africa; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 16 September 2020, about 50 artists, supported by TUMSA, marched to Parliament in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape), demanding for the immediate provisional opening of performance venues up to 70 per cent capacity during the coronavirus lockdown, an allocation of R600 million to the arts sector and an inter-ministerial task group to be set up to review, propose and implement revised strategies to grow the sector. [size=about 50]

On 16 September 2020, about 50 Samora Machel and Kosovo residents, supported by EFF members, marched to the Philippi police station (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) demanding the arrest of a man accused of killing his partner, for protection and visibility of police officers in the area, regular updates on the case from the detective, and the immediate transfer of the case from the local police station to the province with regular updates. [size=about 50]

On 16 September 2020, a group of artists marched to the Union Buildings in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng). The group accused government of being impractical on the criteria for the coronavirus relief fund. [size=no report]

On 16 September 2020, about 100 undertakers blocked the N2 in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) with coffins as they marched to the department of Home Affairs, demanding that the industry be regulated and that by-laws be amended by municipalities to enable cluster storage. [size=about 100]
On 16 September 2020, community members set alight a house in Siloam near Makhado (Vhembe, Limpopo) when they were searching for a man accused of murder. [size=no report]

On 16 September 2020, demonstration action was reported in Dinokana Village, near Zeerust (Ngaka Modiri Molema, North-West) over water-related issues. Police allegedly fired rubber bullets at the house of an elderly woman, breaking the windows of the house and accusing her of encouraging the youth to protest. It is assumed police also used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. [size=no report]
On 17 September 2020, an off-duty police officer was fatally shot inside his car by unknown armed gunmen in Khayelitsha (City of Cape Town, Western Cape).

On 17 September 2020, scores of people, mostly women, demonstrated outside the court in Roodepoort (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) during the bail hearing of two men accused of raping two women and killing the one, demanding bail to be denied. [size=about 20]

column7: Christian Group (South Africa); Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: Around 17 September 2020 (as reported), civil society, churches, unions and business owners demonstrated outside the City Hall in Nelson Mandela Bay also known as Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) to demonstrate against the administration of the municipality. [size=no report]

Around 17 September 2020 (as reported), community members assaulted and almost set alight a teen accused of attempting to rape a young girl in Alexandra (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng). The accused was taken to hospital. [size=no report]

On 17 September 2020, a group of 80 youth demonstrated at the newly renovated Motherwell Shopping Centre (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape), demanding new shops to employ local youths. [size=about 80]

column16: Daily Sun (South Africa); EWN; Citizen (South Africa); Diamond Fields Advertiser; Carletonville Herald
column17: On 17 September 2020, between 150 and 200 former workers of the Fairview stables in Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape), stormed the stables, set 28 horses free and stabbed and killed a horse, demanding their UIF payments. [size=at least 150]
On 17 September 2020, community members in Laingville (West Coast, Western Cape) demonstrated over land issues. [size=no report]

column16: IOL; SABC News; EWN; Capricorn Review; Daily Sun (South Africa)
column17: On 17 September 2020, a soldier shot and injured a man in Mogwadi, formerly called Dendron, (Capricorn, Limpopo) for not wearing a face mask during the national coronavirus lockdown. According to some reports, the man attempted to take the soldier's firearm during a scuffle. The soldier has been arrested.

On 17 September 2020, demonstrators barricaded roads with branches and burning tires and set alight a car in Dinokana Village, near Zeerust (Ngaka Modiri Molema, North-West). Police were on the scene to intervened. The demonstrators pelted stones at police. The demonstration was over water issues in the area. [size=no report]

column7: EFF: Economic Freedom Fighters; Health Workers (South Africa)
column17: On 18 September 2020, health workers, supported by the EFF, marched to the municipal offices in Vereeniging (Sedibeng, Gauteng), demanding their three-month backdated salaries. [size=no report]

On 18 September 2020, about 50 people demonstrated in Durban (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal), demanding the arrest of people accused of looting the coronavirus fund that was started in March. [size=about 50]

Around 18 September 2020 (as reported), residents from Zwide burned tires after waiting for hours for water tankers in Missionvale (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) after communities in Ibhayi, Govan Mbeki, Veeplaas, Soweto on Sea, New Brighton, KwaZakhele, Zwide and Missionvale were left without water. The water tankers ran out of water, causing frustration. [size=no report]

On 18 September 2020, an off duty police officer from the Anti-Gang Unit (AGU) was gunned down at his home in Bishop Lavis (City of Cape Town, Western Cape). One arrest made, reportedly a former rugby player. More arrests were not ruled out as investigations were still under way.

On 18 September 2020, the Ahmed Kathrada Foundation and civil society organizations demonstrated at Constitutional Hill in Braamfontein (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) against corruption. The demonstration was over coronavirus relief funds that were stolen and mismanaged. [size=no report]

On 18 September 2020, Lilydale community members demonstrated outside the court in Mkhuhlu (Ehlanzeni, Mpumalanga) during the bail hearing of two men accused of killing an elderly woman in Lillydale. [size=no report]
On 18 September 2020, community members fatally assaulted a man accused of robbery in Tongaat (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal). [size=no report]

column7: NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa; SACCA: South African Cabin Crew Association; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 18 September 2020, South African Airways (SAA) workers, affiliated with NUMSA and SACCA, demonstrated outside the SAA offices in Kempton Park (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng) after the government missed the deadline to make funding available for a restructuring plan. [size=no report]

On 19 September 2020, about 30 demonstrators gathered at the Fairview stables in Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) to hold a silent demonstration against the killing of a horse during a violent demonstration by workers on Thursday (coded separately). Police intervened to disperse the demonstrators. [size=about 30]

On 19 September 2020, a man was fatally assaulted by community members in Constantia Park, Kroonstad (Fezile Dabi, Free State) after the body of a missing girl was found in his house. Police tried to intervene and were also attacked by the mob. [size=no report]

On 19 September 2020, Better Residents Association (BRA), formerly known as Bushbuckridge Residents Association, members along with EFF members marched to Brooklyn Plantation in Bushbuckridge in Bushbuckridge (Ehlanzeni, Mpumalanga), demanding the resignation of the current president of the party. [size=no report]

On 19 September 2020, about 50 people, allegedly from Somalia, attacked a car of four suspected Nigerian men accused of kidnapping a child in Parow (City of Cape Town, Western Cape). The group overturned the car, pelted it and attempted to set it alight when police intervened by firing rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. [size=about 50]
On 19 September 2020, community members held a convoy in Ladysmith (uThukela, KwaZulu-Natal) through the streets, demonstrating against farm murders. [size=no report]
On 20 September 2020, scores of demonstrators without formal housing marched to the sub-council offices in Khayelitsha (City of Cape Town, Western Cape), demanding basic services. [size=no report]

column16: George Herald (South Africa); Sowetan (South Africa); Times (South Africa); GroundUp
column17: On 20 September 2020, about a thousand community members looted stores and brought traffic to a standstill in Hornlee near Knysna (Eden, Western Cape) after the Red Ants demolished their informal housing in Hornlee. During the demolition, the community members pelted stones at the Red Ants. A police officer was injured after police intervened. Four demonstrators were arrested. Police used stun grenades to disperse the crowd. [size=about 1000]

On 20 September 2020, community members from Phomolomng, Marry Me, Skirlek, Mountain View and several other areas barricaded roads with bricks and burning tires in Mamelodi (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) during a demonstration over service delivery issues. [size=no report]

On 21 September 2020, community members chased away bulldozers hired by the municipality who were paid to work on a new housing project on vacant land next to the community in Bobani Village in Gunguluza near Uitenhage (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape), claiming that the municipality did not consult them. [size=no report]

On 21 September 2020, community members from Phomolomng, Marry Me, Skirlek, Mountain View and several other areas barricaded roads with bricks and burning tires in Mamelodi (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) during a demonstration that started the night before over service delivery issues. [size=no report]

column7: NEHAWU: National Education, Health and Allied Workers Union; Health Workers (South Africa)
column16: Sowetan (South Africa); EWN; News24 (South Africa); Daily Sun (South Africa)
column17: On 21 September 2020, about 60 NEHAWU members demonstrated outside the Union Buildings in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), demanding the presidency to address their concerns that relates to compliance by workplaces with the Occupational and Safety Standards Act, centralization of procurement of PPE and implementation of salary agreements during the coronavirus pandemic. [size=about 60]
On 21 September 2020, community members fatally assaulted two men accused of stock theft in Tsolo (OR Tambo, Eastern Cape). No arrests were made. [size=no report]

On 21 September 2020, Dipateng and Sione community members blocked (no mention of physical barricades) the roads leading to the N1 near Molemole (Capricorn, Limpopo) due to water issues in the areas. [size=no report]

Around 21 September 2020 (as reported), community members demonstrated to demand justice for some children in Orange Farm (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng), demanding the women who were found with a bag containing their clothes to be taken for questioning. There were reportedly chaotic scenes (no mention on what specifically) at the home of children. [size=no report]

column16: Herald (South Africa); Sowetan (South Africa); North Coast Courier; Citizen (South Africa)
column17: On 22 September 2020, community members barricaded the R33 in eBhovini between Pomeroy and Dundee (uMzinyathi, KwaZulu-Natal) with stones and started to dig up the tar road. The demonstration was over a lack of water and electricity in the area. Three people were arrested. [size=at least 3]

On 22 September 2020, community members scuffled with police at the court in Hammanskraal (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) during the court hearing of a man accused of stabbing a woman to death. The community members demonstrated outside the court but then wanted to gain entrance to the court, police blocked them, leading to a reported shuffle. [size=no report]

On 22 September 2020, taxi drivers blocked roads with their taxis in Parker Street next to the Cleary Park Shopping Centre in Betherlsdorp (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape), claiming informal taxis were infringing on their routes. Police were called to the scene to disperse the drivers. [size=no report]

On 22 September 2020, Qolweni informal settlement residents in Plettenberg Bay (Eden, Western Cape) demonstrated over housing for the third day. Roads were barricaded with stones and petrol bombs were thrown on the road. The demonstrators demanded RDP houses to be built in the area. [size=no report]

On 22 September 2020, demonstrators blocked the N6 between East London (Buffalo City, Eastern Cape) and Newlands. A burning truck was also reportedly blocking the traffic, it was not clear whether the truck was torched by the demonstrators at the time of publishing. Reason for demonstration also not known. [size=no report]

On 22 September 2020, Dipateng and Sione community members blocked (no mention of physical barricades) the roads leading to the N1 near Molemole (Capricorn, Limpopo) for the second day due to water issues in the areas. [size=no report]

Around 23 September 2020 (week of), a man was killed by a mob in in Extension 16, Muvhango in Bophelong (Sedibeng, Gauteng) after the mob allegedly caught him stealing from a house. Police found the body surrounded with bricks and sticks. [size=no report]

column16: EWN; Citizen (South Africa); African News Agency; Pretoria News; Daily Dispatch; Times (South Africa)
column17: On 23 September 2020, protesters marched to the Nigerian and Zimbabwean embassies in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) to express their concerns over illegal migrants, human trafficking and drug trafficking. [size=no report]

Around 23 September 2020 (as reported), taxi drivers blocked the corner of Josiah Gumede (Old Main Road) and Anderson Road in Pinetown (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng), demanding the release of arrested taxi drivers and the rescinding of traffic violations tickets. [size=no report]

On 23 September 2020, Qolweni informal settlement residents in Plettenberg Bay (Eden, Western Cape) demonstrated over housing for the second day. Roads were barricaded with stones and petrol bombs were thrown on the road. The demonstrators demanded RDP houses to be built in the area. [size=no report]

On 23 September 2020, community members pelted stones at police after they were reportedly evicted from their illegally built housing in Mokopane (Waterberg, Limpopo). Police used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. [size=no report]

Around 23 September 2020 (as reported), driving school workers demonstrated at the Westonaria Testing Centre (West Rand, Gauteng) demanding that the testing center be opened after it was closed in August due to a break-in. [size=no report]

On 23 September 2020, residents barricaded roads with burning tires and pelted stones at police vehicles in Hangberg (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) following an anti-land invasion operation. [size=no report]

On 24 September 2020, Qolweni informal settlement residents in Plettenberg Bay (Eden, Western Cape) demonstrated for a third day over housing for the third day. Roads were barricaded with stones and petrol bombs were thrown on the road. The demonstrators demanded RDP houses to be built in the area. [size=no report]

Around 24 September 2020 (as reported), hundreds of community members marched to the municipality in Cradock (Chris Hani, Eastern Cape), demanding that all personnel accused of fraud in the municipality be removed from their positions. A fraud case is currently being investigated by the Hawks, the Directorate for Priority Crime Investigation. [size=hundreds]

column7: MKMVA: Umkhonto WeSizwe Military Association; Taxi Drivers (South Africa); Labour Group (South Africa); SANTACO: South Africa National Taxi Council
column17: On 25 September 2020, MKMVA members (former ANC military wing), along with the Unemployed Graduates of South Africa and some taxi associations including Santaco, marched to the ANC offices in Durban (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal) due to frustration of the ANC not addressing corruption, not implementing the 2017 ANC resolutions and not creating job opportunities. [size=no report]

On 25 September 2020, dozens of climate activists, led by Extinction Rebellion marched to the Port Elizabeth City Hall (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) in solidarity with the Global Climate Strike. A major issue for the demonstrators in Port Elizabeth was its water crisis. [size=dozens]

On 25 September 2020, Qolweni informal settlement residents in Plettenberg Bay (Eden, Western Cape) demonstrated for a fourth day over housing. Roads were barricaded with stones and petrol bombs were thrown on the road. The demonstrators demanded RDP houses to be built in the area. [size=no report]

On 25 September 2020, more than 200 community members, supported by EFF members, demonstrated outside the court in Alexandria (Sarah Baartman, Eastern Cape) during the hearing of a man accused of stabbing a woman who is currently in the hospital, demanding that bail be denied. [size=more than 200]

Around 26 September 2020 (weekend of), residents of the Kanana informal settlement in Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) demolished 18 informal houses belonging to newer residents after they were told that electrification in the area have been delayed due to the new residents. [size=no report]

On 27 September 2020, a group of environment activists demonstrated in Tokai (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) after the relocation of a baboon. The demonstrators accused the city of not consulting the community and of the mistreatment of all baboons in the city. [size=no report]

Around 28 September 2020 (as reported), hundreds of rugby fans demonstrated at the Buffalo City Stadium in East London (Buffalo City, Eastern Cape) against the decision to lease the stadium to Chippa United (a soccer club). [size=hundreds]

On 28 September 2020, Qolweni informal settlement residents in Plettenberg Bay (Eden, Western Cape) demonstrated over housing. The demonstrators demanded RDP houses to be build in the area. Demonstration action also erupted last week Tuesday and lasted until Friday (coded separately). [size=no report]

Around 28 September 2020 (beginning of week), workers, mostly security guards, general workers and cleaners, demonstrated outside the University of Venda's Univen Innovative Growth Company at Barotta farm in Thohoyandou (Vhembe, Limpopo), demanding salary increase. [size=no report]

column16: Daily Sun (South Africa); Times (South Africa); EWN; GardaWorld; SABC News; Sowetan (South Africa); Herald (South Africa)
column17: On 28 September 2020, community members from various informal settlements including Baby Are You Coming, Anglas Station and Nareng, barricaded roads in Lawley, Lenasia South and Ennerdale (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) with burning tires, rocks and rubble. The demonstration was over the Red Ants planning to demolish their informal housing, reportedly illegally build. Police used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. The demonstrators pelted stones at police. [size=no report]

column16: EWN; GardaWorld; SABC News; Herald (South Africa); Sowetan (South Africa); Times (South Africa); Daily Sun (South Africa)
column17: On 28 September 2020, community members from various informal settlements including Baby Are You Coming, Anglas Station and Nareng, barricaded roads in Lawley (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng), Lenasia South and Ennerdale with burning tires, rocks and rubble. The demonstrators pelted stones at police. [size=no report]

On 28 September 2020, family and friends of a woman who was killed by her partner demonstrated outside the court during the bail hearing of the accused in Wynberg (City of Cape Town, Western Cape), demanding bail to be denied. [size=no report]
On 28 September 2020, residents of Mdlankomo village demonstrated on the R61 between Mthatha (OR Tambo, Eastern Cape) and Libode, demanding clean water. [size=no report]
On 29 September 2020, motorists burned tires in front of the license department in Vanderbijlpark (Sedibeng, Gauteng) in frustration over testing center booking dates. [size=no report]

On 29 September 2020, Codeta Disadvantaged Taxi Association (DTA) members marched in George (Eden, Western Cape) to hand over a memorandum calling for the association be registered, permits to be given to drivers, and for competition among the taxis and busses to be allowed. [size=no report]

On 29 September 2020, Qolweni informal settlement residents in Plettenberg Bay (Eden, Western Cape) demonstrated over housing for the second day. The demonstrators demanded RDP houses to be build in the area. Police used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. Demonstration action also erupted last week Tuesday and lasted until Friday (coded separately). [size=no report]

Demonstration action were also reported at the Tutuka, Kendal, Lethabo and Majuba power stations (coded separately). [size=hundreds]

Around 29 September 2020 (as reported), residents blocked (no mention of physical barriers) the R103 between Colenso (uThukela, KwaZulu-Natal) and Frere in demonstration against a lack of housing and water in the area. [size=no report]

Around 29 September 2020 (as reported), about 40 residents and farm workers demonstrated outside the court in Newcastle (Amajuba, KwaZulu-Natal) during the bail hearing of a man accused of killing a couple on their farm a month ago. [size=about 40]

On 29 September 2020, demonstrators barricaded roads with burning tires in Sithembile, Glencoe near Dundee (uMzinyathi, KwaZulu-Natal) after Eskom workers moved to remove illegal electricity connections in the area. [size=no report]
On 29 September 2020, a large group demonstrated outside the Endumeni Municipality in Dundee (uMzinyathi, KwaZulu-Natal) to hand over a memorandum. No further information available. [size=large]

column7: Labour Group (South Africa); NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: On 30 September 2020, NUMSA members marched to the office of Venture in Rosslyn (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), accusing the managers of hostile action against workers. Before the national coronavirus lockdown in March, the company dismissed 21 workers for downing tools due to a lack of water at the company site. [size=no report]
On 30 September 2020, residents barricaded roads in Philippi (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) with burning rubble. The demonstration was over uncollected garbage for three months. [size=no report]

On 30 September 2020, small business owners barricaded the N2 between Mount Frere (Alfred Nzo, Eastern Cape) and Kokstad with cars and big rocks, accusing the municipality of side lining them for government tenders. Police intervened to reopen the road. [size=no report]

On 30 September 2020, Qolweni informal settlement residents in Plettenberg Bay (Eden, Western Cape) demonstrated over housing for the third day. The demonstrators demanded RDP houses to be build in the area. Demonstration action also erupted last week Tuesday and lasted until Friday (coded separately). [size=no report]

On 30 September 2020, dozens of residents for several informal settlement communities in Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) barricaded roads with burning tires, trees, rubbish and rocks, demanding to be relocated. [size=dozens]

Around 30 September 2020 (week of), Greyton residents demonstrated outside the Theewaterskloof municipal offices in or near Caledon (Overberg, Western Cape) against the sale of an eight hectare piece of land, demanding the land to be used for houses for the community. [size=no report]

column7: Labour Group (South Africa); NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa
column17: On 30 September 2020, dozens of workers from various sectors affiliated to NUMSA demonstrated outside the Labor Department and Unemployment Insurance Fund (UIF) provincial offices in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape). The demonstrators demanded their delayed Temporary Employee Relief Scheme (TERS) allocated to them during the national coronavirus lockdown and an investigation and arrest of officials found to have been involved in corruption. [size=dozens]

On 30 September 2020, Stilwater, Zaailaagte, Schotchill and Scheepersnek community members, including farmers, marched to the AbaQulusi Local Municipality in Vryheid (Zululand, KwaZulu-Natal) to hand over a memorandum that addresses inadequate supply of electricity and water interruptions in the area. [size=no report]
On 30 September 2020, taxi drivers blocked roads with their taxis in Seshego (Capricorn, Limpopo) over route disputes. [size=no report]
On 1 October 2020, pupils and parents demonstrated at the Vaal High School in Vanderbijlpark (Sedibeng, Gauteng) following allegations of sexual misconduct at the school. [size=no report]

On 1 October 2020, small business owners demonstrated at the district municipality offices in or near Mount Frere (Alfred Nzo, Eastern Cape), blocking workers from entering. The demonstrators accused the municipality of side lining them for government tenders. [size=no report]

On 1 October 2020, dozens of residents for several informal settlement communities in Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) continued to demonstrate for a second day. Roads were barricaded with guardrails and pelted stones at vehicles, demanding to be relocated. [size=dozens]

On 1 October 2020, Bobani Village residents, near Uitenhage (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape), attacked a man suspected of stealing a cell phone and demolished his house. Police intervened and took the man away. [size=no report]

column7: Yoruba Ethnic Group (Nigeria); Biafra Communal Group (Nigeria)
column17: On 1 October 2020, over 100 people from the Yoruba diaspora marched to the British High Commission and the Nigerian embassy in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), calling for the establishment of the Oduduwa Republic. The demonstrators were joined by a dozen of people from the Biafran diaspora, who had their own memorandum, called for similar autonomy for that region. [size=over 100]

On 1 October 2020, about 70 elderly people demonstrated outside the William Moffett Expressway in Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) after the social development cut subsidies during the national coronavirus lockdown. [size=about 70]
On 1 October 2020, community members marched in Woodlands (uMgungundlovu, KwaZulu-Natal) over the increasing sexual violence happening in the area. [size=no report]
On 1 October 2020, about 100 EFF members marched to the Durban City Hall (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal), accusing city officials of corruption. [size=about 100]

column7: ANCWL: African National Congress Womens League; Women (South Africa)
column17: On 1 October 2020, political party supporters, assumed EFF and ANCWL, reportedly scuffled outside the court in Mbombela, formally known as Nelspruit (Ehlanzeni, Mpumalanga) during the court hearing of a MEC and PEC member accused of sexually assaulting two young girls. According to reports, the ANCWL supported the accused while the EFF supported the victims. [size=no report]

column7: SDCEA: South Durban Environmental Alliance; ABMSM: Abahlali Basemjondolo Shack Dwellers Movement; ACM: Active Citizen Movement
column17: On 2 October 2020, about 200 climate activists, including members from SDCEA, ABMSM, and ACM, marched to the Durban City Hall (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal), calling for greater action on climate change. [size=about 200]

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 2 October 2020, ANCYL members marched to the Babelegi Industrial Park in Hammanskraal in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), demanding employment. [size=no report]

On 2 October 2020, members of the People's Movement gathered outside the Bloemfontein court (Mangaung, Free State) during the court hearing of seven suspects accused of corruption relating to an asbestos project, calling for the accused to be charged. ANC members also gathered outside the court in support of the accused, calling for senior members of the ANC to be charged. [size=no report]
On 5 October 2020, demonstrators blocked the N12 near Bedfordview (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng) with trucks and motor vehicles. The reason for demonstration not reported. [size=no report]

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; NUMSA: National Union of Metalworkers of South Africa; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 5 October 2020, COSATU and NUMSA members demonstrated outside the Maitland police station (City of Cape Town, Western Cape), demanding the removal of a station commander accused of sexually harassing workers. [size=no report]

On 5 October 2020, more than 200 NSFAS (National Student Financial Aid Scheme) workers demonstrated outside the offices in Wynberg (City of Cape Town, Western Cape), demanding higher salaries. [size=more than 200]

On 5 October 2020, about 100 Early Childhood Development Centre staff and parents demonstrated outside the Social Development Department office in New Brighton (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape), pleading with the department for assistance with grants. The workers at the centers have not received salaries during the national coronavirus lockdown. [size=about 100]

On 5 October 2020, community members barricaded roads with burning tires in Kleinmond (Overberg, Western Cape) after five men were arrested for abalone poaching. Demonstrators pelted stones at police who used rubber bullets to disperse the crowd. A journalist was seriously injured when a brick was smashed through his car window. The demonstrators told journalists that although illegal, the poaching of abalone sustains the community. [size=no report]
On 5 October 2020, Gautrain workers demonstrated outside the offices of the Bombela Operating Company in Midrand (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng), demanding increased wages. [size=no report]

column16: Pretoria News; Daily Sun (South Africa); EWN; Citizen (South Africa)
column17: On 5 October 2020, members of the Truckers Association of South Africa demonstrated outside the Department of Transport in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), demanding the regulation of the industry with operating licenses and monitoring by the department. [size=no report]

On 6 October 2020, more than 100 workers from various sectors marched through Johannesburg (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) to hand over a memorandum with a list of demands relating job losses, unemployment and corruption. [size=more than 100]

column7: CWU: Communication Workers Union; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 6 October 2020, CWU members marched to the department of higher education offices in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng), accusing the department of exploiting them. The workers demanded a wage increase. [size=no report]
On 6 October 2020, workers demonstrated outside the Sappi Southern Africa Umkomaas Mill (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal), demanding a salary increase. [size=no report]

column16: IOL; Herald (South Africa); Times (South Africa); Sowetan (South Africa); News24 (South Africa)
column17: On 6 October 2020, about 1500 of farmers gathered in front of the court in Senekal (Thabo Mofutsanyana, Free State) during the hearing of two men accused of killing a farmer. The crowd demanded the suspects to be handed over to them. The demonstrators accused government of not protecting farmers. Two gunshots were fired (not certain by who), a police vehicle was overturned and set alight, and court property were damaged. A number of DA supporters were also part of the demonstration but dispersed when the crowd turned violent. Police arrested one demonstrator. [size=about 1500]

column7: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: On 7 October 2020, about 50 ANCYL members demonstrated outside the Senekal police station in Senekal (Thabo Mofutsanyana, Free State) against the demonstration action by farmers the day before (coded separately). The group criticized the police for having double standards when different race groups demonstrate. [size=about 50]

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 7 October 2020, dozens of COSATU supporters gathered at Princess Park in Estcourt (uThukela, KwaZulu-Natal) to show support for the national call by COSATU for peaceful demonstrations against issues around public transport, health and safety, corruption, attacks on collective bargaining, retrenchment and unemployment, gender-based violence and the gender pay gap. [size=dozens]
On 7 October 2020, union members demonstrated outside the Dundee hospital (uMzinyathi, KwaZulu-Natal) ahead of the planned national strike organized by COSATU. [size=no report]

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 7 October 2020, members of COSATU marched in Johannesburg (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) against state capture, corruption and gender-based violence. Workers also demanded compliance with the occupational health and safety direction and regulations by all employers, creation of decent jobs, protection of commuters and workers. [size=no report]

column7: Labour Group (South Africa); COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; SAFTU: South African Federation of Trade Unions; NACTU: National Council of Trade Unions; FEDUSA: Federation of Unions of South Africa
column17: On 7 October 2020, about 1000 members of Cosatu, Saftu, Nactu and Fedusa marched to Port Elizabeth City Hall (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) against what they call exploitation of workers by government. [size=about 1000]

[size=around 450]

column17: On 7 October 2020, thousands members of COSATU, DENOSA and SAFTU marched in Durban (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal) against issues around public transport, health and safety, corruption, attacks on collective bargaining, retrenchment and unemployment, gender-based violence and the gender pay gap. [size=thousands]

column7: COSATU: Congress of South African Trade Unions; SAFTU: South African Federation of Trade Unions; SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union; SADTU: South African Democratic Teachers Union; DENOSA: Democratic Nursing Organisation of South Africa; Labour Group (South Africa)
column17: On 7 October 2020, members of COSATU, SAMWU, SADTU, DENOSA and SAFTU marched to the National Treasury in the Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) against state capture, corruption and gender-based violence. Workers also demanded compliance with the occupational health and safety direction and regulations by all employers, creation of decent jobs, protection of commuters and workers. [size=no report]

On 8 October 2020, nearly 200 people petrol bombed and stoned four houses in the communities of Booysens Park and Marikana, Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape). The event happened after a man was shot and killed by unidentified individuals in the region on 5 October. No reports on injuries. [size=nearly 200]
On 8 October 2020, a mob set alight a business, the house and vehicle belonging to a man accused of murder in GaRapitsi, Itireleng Section near Bolobedu (Mopani, Limpopo). [size=no report]

On 8 October 2020, supporters of the former president who is currently being investigated for corruption and state capture marched to the Zondo Commission in Johannesburg (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng), accusing the commission of political motivated attacks on the former president. The march also came after it was reported that an alleged warrant of arrest will be execute against the current ANC secretary general. [size=no report]

On 9 October 2020, supporters, including uMkhonto we Sizwe Military Veterans Association members, of the former president who is currently being investigated for corruption and state capture marched to the Constitutional Court in Johannesburg (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng), demanding the resignation of the resignation of the deputy chief justice of the Judicial Commission of Inquiry into Allegations of State Capture to step down, accusing him of bias. [size=no report]

On 9 October 2020, residents barricaded the R63 near Cookhouse (Cacadu, Eastern Cape) with burning tires and large stones. The demonstrators accused businesses in the area of not employing people from Cookhouse. [size=no report]
On 11 October 2020, a man was shot and injured by police officers in Ngcobo (Amathole, Eastern Cape). According to the police officers, he disobeyed a stop sign.

On 12 October 2020, protesters gathered in KwaMashu (eThekwini, Kwa-Zulu-Natal) to protest against the redrawing of municipal lines that moved residents into a different ward. A man died during the protest after being struck by an armoured vehicle belonging to the South African police forces. Some accounts say the vehicle deliberately hit the man, while a police spokesperson said the man ran straight into the vehicle. [size=no report]

column16: IOL; Times (South Africa); Mercury (South Africa); Sowetan (South Africa)
column17: On 12 October 2020, approximately 600 people gathered in Reservoir Hills (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal), demanding that their electricity connections be restored. Demonstrators stoned 10 vehicles, looted a nearby liquor store and butchery, burned tires, and burned a municipal bus and a car belonging to the Reservoir Hills CPF chairperson. Police arrested 10 demonstrators and said some police officers were injured during clashes with them. [size=approximately 600]

On 12 October 2020, protesters gathered in Ulundi (Zululand, KwaZulu-Natal) demanding the arrest of police officers allegedly involved in the murder of a taxi driver. Protesters blockaded one of the main roades in Ulundi. Police forces arrested 5 protesters. [size=no report]

On 12 October 2020, protesters demanded that the Okhahlamba Local Municipality Speaker be removed from office for misconduct where they gathered in Bergville (uThukela, KwaZulu-Natal). [size=no report]

On 12 October 2020, e-hailing drivers working for Bolt protested at the company's headquarters in Bryanston (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) and allegedly stormed the company's offices. South African police intervened and fired rubber bullets to disperse the protests. [size=no report]

column7: MKVMA: Mkhonto weSizwe Military Veterans Association
column17: On 12 October 2020, members of Umkhonto we Sizwe Military Veterans Association protested in Newtown (City of Johannesburg, Guateng) against the African National Congress (ANC), claiming that the ANC is tarnishing the constitution. [size=no report]
On 13 October 2020, protesters gathered in Wentworth (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal) because they claimed protocols were not being properly followed in the allocation of houses. [size=no report]

On 13 October 2020, at least 50 protesters staged a march outside of the Potchefstroom Magistrate Court in Potchefstroom (Dr Kenneth Kaunda, North-West), where there was a hearing for suspects in a murder case. The protesters carried signs such as ""No farmers, no food,"" ""We seek justice,"" and ""Boer life matters."" [size=at least 50]

Around 13 October 2020 (as reported), approximately 300 youth from the South Durban Community Environmental Alliance (SDCEA) staged a climate protest in Durban (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal), calling for action to combat climate change. [size=300]

Around 13 October 2020 (as reported), the South Durban Community Environmental Alliance (SDCEA) and community members protested around Wentworth (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal) against trucking violations causing increased traffic and accidents. [size=no report]

On 14 October 2020, protesters gathered outside the Pinetown Magistrate Court in Pinetown (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) to protest against the imprisonment of four men accused of shooting peopled alleged to have stolen from them. [size=no report]

On 15 October 2020, dozens of parents gathered in front of a school in Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape), and blocked the school entrance in a demonstration over delays of a fencing project. [size=dozens]
On 15 October 2020, 4 schools were set on fire by unidentified individuals in Moruleng (Bojanala Platinum, North-West).
Around 15 October 2020 (week of), a taxi driver was tortured and beaten to death by police officers inside his house in Ulundi (Zululand, KwaZulu-Natal).

Around 15 October 2020 (week of), a group set tires on fire during a demonstration on the main R66 road in Ulundi (Zululand, KwaZulu-Natal) after a taxi driver was killed by police inside his house. The group also damaged cars with stones. [size=no report]

On 15 October 2020, over 100 workers of a food and beverage company set two of the company's vehicles on fire and turned over another one in Tembisa (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng) during a demonstration concerning wage disputes. The vehicles were taking workers home and were being accompanied by a security company. No one was injured. [size=over 100]
On 15 October 2020, about 50 Molemole local residents marched in Botlokwa demanding better government services in Molemole town (Capricorn, Limpopo). They demanded better policing. [size=about 50]

On 15 October 2020, about 150 farm workers staged a protest from Hanover street to parliament in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape). They protested against the response to the department of agriculture, land reform and rural development's latest land reform strategy. They demanding an urgent meeting with the minister. [size=about 150]

On 16 October 2020, Mbizane and Henley Dam residents blocked roads in Msunduzi (uMgungundlovu, KwaZulu-Natal) in a demonstration to demand a community hall, the repair of a road, and a dependable water supply. [size=no report]

On 16 October 2020, a group gathered in the N10 highway, Cookhouse (Cacadu, Eastern Cape) to demand the creation of jobs in the multi-purpose industrial park in Somerset East. The police dispersed the group. [size=no report]

On 16 October 2020, about 70 demonstrators took to the streets of Musina (Vhembe, Limpopo) to demand that 85% of all local jobs go to South African residents in the city. The group also demanded greater police visibility at night, and a satellite station at Matswale township, among other things. [size=about 70]

On 16 October 2020, taxi drivers blocked Crompton Street in eThekwini (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal) during a inspection of the Go!Durban Integrated Rapid Public Transport Network, demanding authorities to address their grievances. [size=no report]

On 16 October 2020, local residents have protested and delivered a memorandum of grievances to Dobsonville police in Soweto town (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng). They demanded more patrols and better service from police. [size=no report]

On 16 October 2020, local residents of various informal settlements demonstrated by blocking Effingham and Umhlangane roads with burning tires and rubble in Durban town (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal). The demonstration was in response to the demolition of two shacks at Sim Place settlement by the land invasion unit. [size=no report]

On 16 October 2020, Bhekumthetho (Section C) community members took to the streets and marched until the AbaQulusi Local Municipality offices (Section A) in Mondlo (Zululand, KwaZulu-Natal) in a demonstration for better infrastructure in the region. [size=no report]

On 17 October 2020, a man was beaten to death and set on fire by a mob in the Phola Park in Thokoza (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng). The man had raped and killed a girl, he was caught by residents as he tried to set her on fire in a bin. [size=no report]

On 17 October 2020, residents and members of various Khoisan tribes gathered in Pacaltsdorp, George (Eden, Western Cape) in a demonstration against developmental projects in the region, as the land carries historical significance for the group. [size=no report]
On 17 October 2020, unknown gunmen shot and killed the station commander of the Groblersdal police station in front of his house at Maganagobuswa village in Groblersdal town (Sekhukhune, Limpopo).
On 18 October 2020, at least 200 people marched along the Beach Road in Port Elizabeth (Nelson Mandela Bay, Eastern Cape) in a demonstration in support of Palestine. [size=at least 200]

On 19 October 2020, a group gathered in front of a health clinic in Soweto (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) in a demonstration against ill-treatment, unfriendly staff, and lack of adequate facilities. [size=no report]

column7: ABMSM: Abahlali Basemjondolo Shack Dwellers Movement
column16: Sowetan (South Africa); GroundUp; Herald (South Africa); Times (South Africa); Mercury (South Africa); Daily Sun (South Africa)
column17: On 19 October 2020, hundreds of Abahlali baseMjondolo members and supporters took to the streets of Durban (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal) in a demonstration against corruption, forced evictions, violence, among other things. [size=hundreds]

Around 19 October 2020 (as reported), Gandlanani village residents set houses and vehicles belonging to a businessman and 2 of his employees on fire in Giyani (Mopani, Limpopo) after they were pointed out as responsible for the disappearance of a man. A person was seriously injured; 23 people were arrested. [size=no report]

On 19 October 2020, members of a school's governing body and parents set six mobile classrooms and one school classroom on fire in Katlehong (Ekurhuleni, Gauteng). The group was demanding brick and mortar buildings instead of prefabricated mobile classrooms. Several people were arrested. [size=no reports]

column7: PBI: Local Concerned Residents; DA: Democratic Alliance; ANC: African National Congress; Icosa: Independent Civic Organisation of South Africa
column17: On 19 October 2020, members of the PBI, DA, ANC and Icosa gathered in front of the George Magistrate's Court (Eden, Western Cape) in a demonstration against the possible bail release of the suspect of killing a pregnant woman. Members of different parties were accusing the others of using the event for political purposes. [size=no report]

On 19 October 2020, about 50 Mbizane and Henley Dam residents set tires on fire and threw objects against the police in Msunduzi (uMgungundlovu, KwaZulu-Natal) during a demonstration to demand a community hall, the repair of a road, and a dependable water supply. The police used rubber bullets and tear gas to disperse the group. No reports on injuries. [size=about 50]
On 19 October 2020, an electricity substation was set on fire and vandalized by unidentified individuals in the north of Westville (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal).

On 20 October 2020, an eSwatini national was shot and killed by police officers in the border post of Mananga (Ehlanzeni, Mpumalanga). The man and three other friends were passing through the informal crossing between the two countries to avoid coronavirus-related inquiries.

On 20 October 2020, a miner was shot with a rubber bullet and killed by private security personnel in the Grootegeluk mine, near Lephalale (Waterberg, Limpopo). The event happened after a group of miners invaded a private property and set alight to part of the veld and a conveyor belt. Ongoing demonstrations are being reported regarding demands of miners concerning local recruitment, skills development and social investment initiatives, among others. [size=no report]

On 20 October 2020, Dobsonville residents gathered in front of the Roodepoort Magistrates court (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) in a demonstration to demand justice in the case of the sexual assault and death of two women in July. [size=no report]
On 21 October 2020, over 100 people took to the streets of central Johannesburg (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) to demand land and housing through the Rapid Land Release Programme. [size=over 100]
On 21 October 2020, Nigeria nationals took to the street in Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) in a demonstration in support of the #EndSARS movement (Nigeria). [size=no report]
On 21 October 2020, about 400 people took to the street in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) in a demonstration in support of the #endSARS movement (Nigeria). [size=about 400]

column9: ANCYL: African National Congress Youth League
column17: On 21 October 2020, an ANCYL leader was shot and killed by unidentified individuals outside the Coastal TVET College, Umbumbulu (eThekwini, KwaZulu-Natal). Motivation and authorship are unknown.

On 21 October 2020, the police fired rubber bullets against a group of employees of a mill company in Richards Bay (uThungulu, KwaZulu-Natal) during a demonstration over salaries dispute. The employees are in strike for 3 weeks. 4 people were injured. [size=no report]

column9: Former Military Forces of South Africa (1994-)
column17: On 22 October 2020, private security personal shot former Military officers who were occupying a plot of land on the Tsineng road near the R31 in Kuruman (John Taolo Gaetsewe, Northern Cape). No reports on injuries.

On 22 October 2020, a group blocked roads in the Msobomvu area and clashed with the police in Butterworth (Amathole, Eastern Cape) during a demonstration over lack of water. 11 people were arrested. [size=no report]

On 22 October 2020, a group of people threw stones and blocked the N2 highway near Khayelitsha (City of Cape Town, Western Cape). The group was dispersed by the police; the motivation for the demonstration was unknown. [size=no report]

On 22 October 2020, about 200 people gathered at the intersection between Wale and Bree streets, Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) in a demonstration in support of survivors and victims of gender-based violence and sexual assault. [size=about 200]

Around 22 October 2020 (as reported), a group of hospitality workers gathered outside Parliament in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) in a demonstration to demand the payment of UIF/Ters and retrenchments. [size=no report]

column7: SAMWU: South African Municipal Workers Union; Police Forces of South Africa (1994-)
column17: On 22 October 2020, members of the metro police, linked to the SAMWU, blocked the entrance of the Pretoria West headquarters, Pretoria (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) in a demonstration against the Metro Police Department chief Lieutenant-General. [size=no report]

column16: Times (South Africa); Pretoria News; Citizen (South Africa)
column17: On 23 October 2020, supporters of a self-proclaimed prophet of an evangelical church gathered in front of the Pretoria magistrate's court (City of Tshwane, Gauteng) in support of the man and his wife, arrested for fraud, and to demand their bail. [size=no report]

On 23 October 2020, a group marched to the uMngungundlovu District Municipality in Pietermaritzburg (uMgungundlovu, KwaZulu-Natal) to demand the removal of officials and councilors who have been accused of corruption from the office. [size=no report]

On 24 October 2020, supporters of the Move One Million took to the streets in Johannesburg (City of Johannesburg, Gauteng) in a demonstration against those 'who consider themselves above the law'. The group delivered a memorandum in the Constitution Hill. [size=no report]

On 24 October 2020, supporters of the Move One Million took to the streets in Cape Town (City of Cape Town, Western Cape) in a demonstration against those 'who consider themselves above the law'. The group delivered a memorandum in the Parliament. [size=no report]

On Wednesday, more than 30 people were reportedly injured and shops were forced to close at Jerera Growth Point in Zaka, Masvingo after another group of soldiers attacked villagers.

column6: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
column17: 400 ZANU PF youths besieged the MDC district office in Mbare and assaulted 24 of its youth who guard the premises. Mugabes mob allegedly smashed all the windows to the centre and stole three sets of computers and vandalised the office furniture.

column17: Zimbabwean police drove out scores of so-called war veterans and supporters of President Robert Mugabe after they declared themselves new owners of several tourist resorts near Lake Chivero, according to a minister and media reports.

column6: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
column17: At least five MDC activists were left injured, two of them seriously, on Monday night in a fresh wave of political violence to hit the capital city, Harare. MDC activists were set upon by local ZANU PF youths with rocks, bricks, iron bars and other weapons, forcing neighbours in the vicinity to flee.

column7: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
column17: Police stood-by as ZANU-PF youths in Bulawayo temporarily took over an apartment block, chanting indigenisation slogans, to prevent the Indian owner from evicting tenants over unpaid rent. The demonstration caused a disruption to traffic in the city as the building is close to a busy taxi rank. Despite this, the police did nothing to stop the disorder.

column6: MDC-T: Movement for Democratic Change (Tsvangirai Faction)
column17: WHAT is believed to be a petrol bomb was detonated at Mbares Siya-So market stalls yesterday in what preliminary investigations indicate was an attack by suspected MDC-T youths.

column6: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
column17: On Saturday ZANU PF youths attacked several MDC activists in Mbare and left five of them seriously injured. The MDC MP for Mbare, Piniel Denga, said he believes his constituency has been earmarked as the nerve centre because of its links to all major transport routes in Zimbabwe.

column7: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
column17: Harare came to a standstill on Monday when a ZANU PF mob engulfed the city in chaos, destroying property worth thousands of dollars, mainly belonging to foreign owned companies.

column17: . On Monday the market stalls run by an Mbare Zanu-PF activist were petrol-bombed.

column17: On Monday a group of ZANU-PF youths caused commotion as they went on a rampage in the Central Business District, looting property in protestover foreign ownership, targeting businesses owned by West African and Chinese nationals. During the march, they sang a Shona song which translates to: """"President Mugabe do not worry; we are your soldiers.""""

column6: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
column17: MUNN Marketing, the distributors of three Alpha Media Holdings three newspapers and several other leading South African publications, says attacksagainst its vendors by Zanu PF supporters and suspected state agents have intensified countrywide.

column17: WOZA held a demonstration attended by over 1,800 people to protest escalating violence. Police dispersed the crowds by driving vehicles through the gathering.

column17: Police in Harare on Tuesday tried to block a peaceful demonstration by pressure group Women of Zimbabwe Arise (WOZA), who were attempting to hand over a list of demands to parliament. About 10 WOZA members managed to push past the riot police and make their way to parliament, where they delivered the groups list of demands regarding the constitutional reform process and the state of the unity government.
Followers of renegade Anglican bishop kill Christian woman in Harare

A member of the mainstream faction of the Zimbabwe Anglican church was raped and murdered by unidentified assailants, suspected to be supporters of the ardent ZANU-PF Anglican faction, led by Dr. Nolbert Kunonga. Death threats were received by other members of the mainstream church.
Zimbabwean police tortured some of the 46 rights activists facing treason charges after their arrest last week at a meeting to discuss the massprotests in Egypt, a lawyer said on Thursday.

column6: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
column17: Hundreds of villagers from Nyakomba in Nyanga North are fleeing violence orchestrated by ZANU PF, and on Wednesday crossed the border into Mozambique. At Nyabvure primary school the militia targeted a teacher, identified as Wellington Tazangira, and beat him up because he supports the MDC.

column6: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
column17: Hundreds of villagers from Nyakomba in Nyanga North are fleeing violence orchestrated by ZANU PF, and on Wednesday crossed the border into Mozambique. ZANU PF militia in three truck loads stormed the area and started going house to house looking for MDC supporters.

column6: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
column17: Three MDC members from Mutare North are recovering, after they were assaulted by a mob of ZANU PF activists, wielding axes on Thursday.

column6: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
column7: ZNLWVA: Zimbabwe National Liberation War Veterans Association

Youth militia and war vets rampaged through the Mapfurutse village on Friday night, destroying homes and looting property, accusing people of being MDC supporters.

column9: WOZA: Women of Zimbabwe Arise; Women (Zimbabwe)

column6: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
column17: Also on Monday there was the case of MDC youth activist Patrick Kamanga, who his party says was abducted Monday morning by a group of ZANU PF thugs in the Magaba area of Mbare in Harare.

column6: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
column17: Germany has protested to the Zimbabwe Foreign Affairs Ministry this week after its ambassador, Albrecht Conze, was attacked by a suspected ZANU PF mob in Harare on Tuesday. A mob attacked the ambassadors official vehicle while he was travelling from the German Embassy on Tuesday night.

Media rights groups have expressed their shock and condemnation after a journalist, who is 6 months pregnant, was assaulted by a man who boasted about being related to a director of the Central Intelligence Organisation (CIO).

column6: Military Forces of Zimbabwe (1987-2017) Central Intelligence Organization
column17: Job Sikhala, president of the MDC 99 party, was admitted to a hospital in Harare on Thursday, a day after being granted bail on unspecified charges. The former MP for St Marys told SW Radio Africa that he was assaulted by intelligence agents while in police custody and is not able to walk unassisted.

column7: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
column17: ZANU PF youths under the Upfumi Kuvadiki (Wealth to the Youths) group have seized Easipark, a South African company which had been contracted to manage parking and towing services in Harare.

column17: On Monday in Bulawayo, Women and Men of Zimbabwe Arise (WOZA) ploughed ahead with their International Womens Day march, protesting against the torture of members by the police and calling on South African President Jacob Zuma to help end the violence.

column9: ZCTU: Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions; Women (Zimbabwe)
column17: Three women who participated in a Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions (ZCTU) protest march were forced to strip off their clothes in the city centre of Bulawayo by the police, their regional leader has said. One of the three is heavily pregnant. A group of protesters storm a police station an attempt to release their colleagues, who had been arrested for breaking the land survey law. Twenty-five of rioters are arrested.

column9: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
column17: Land seizure: Several Zanu PF supporters in Masvingo, Midlands and Mashonaland East province were in the ""past few weeks"" evicted from farms they had occupied for over a decade. The evections are suspected to be politically motivated.

column9: ZANU-PF: Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front
column17: Property destruction: The Zanu PF supporters home is destroyed by police in a suspected political act.
